thread.title: Texas emergency teams witness aurora borealis in North Carolina amid hurricane relief
thread.title_full: Texas emergency teams witness aurora borealis in North Carolina amid hurricane relief

author: Tara Brolley
title: Texas emergency teams witness aurora borealis in North Carolina amid hurricane relief
text:
Texas emergency responders deployed to North Carolina for hurricane relief efforts were treated to a rare spectacle: the aurora borealis.
The Texas Division of Emergency Management (TDEM) shared on social media that their personnel witnessed the northern lights during their deployment to assist with recovery from Hurricane Helene.
"North Carolina gives our deployed Texans the gift of Aurora Borealis during their deployment to support hurricane relief efforts," TDEM posted on X.
RELATED | Texas deploys emergency teams to Florida and Tennessee amid hurricane threats
This unexpected celestial show comes amid a busy hurricane season that has seen multiple states mobilizing resources to help affected areas.
Earlier this week, Texas Gov. Greg Abbott announced the deployment of emergency response and recovery resources to Florida and Tennessee. Texas A&M Task Force 1 swiftwater rescue teams were sent to Florida in preparation for Hurricane Milton, which hit land as a Category 3 Wednesday night.
"Texas is swiftly deploying emergency response personnel and resources to Florida as Hurricane Milton prepares to make landfall," Abbott said at the time.
Milton, the second fastest intensifying storm on record in the Atlantic basin, reached peak winds of 180 mph.
Texas has also sent additional resources to Tennessee and previously deployed teams to North Carolina and Georgia to assist with Hurricane Helene recovery efforts.
